meanings.def: of a particular age
examples: be… years, months, etc. old The baby was only a few hours old.
In those days most people left school when they were only fifteen years old.
At thirty years old, he was already earning £40 000 a year.
two fourteen-year-old boys
a class for five-year-olds (= children who are five)
I didn't think she was old enough for the responsibility.
He's not too old to play Romeo.
How old is this building?
He's the oldest player in the team.
She's much older than me.
My two older sisters and I shared a bedroom.
He's old enough by now to manage his own affairs.
You are as old as you feel.

meanings.def: having lived for a long time; no longer young
examples: to get/grow old
The old man lay propped up on cushions.
a little old lady
She was a woman grown old before her time (= who looked older than she was).
He was beginning to look old.
Tom was the last surviving member of the older generation of the family.
She’s getting old—she’s 75 next year.
She is very busy caring for two elderly relatives.
Having aged relatives to stay in your house can be quite stressful.
Everyone in my family is exceptionally long-lived.
clothes for the mature woman
She was fairly old when she got married.
The way the young people rushed about made her feel old.
She's getting old—she's 75 next year.
We're all getting older.

meanings.def: old people
examples: The old feel the cold more than the young.

meanings.def: having existed or been used for a long time
examples: old habits
He always gives the same old excuses.
This carpet's getting pretty old now.
a beautiful old farmhouse
My brother is older than me.
The palace is the oldest building in the city.
my older/​elder sister
the elder/​older of their two children
I’m the eldest/​oldest in the family.
It's a very old tradition.
It's one of the oldest remaining parts of the church.
It's the world's oldest surviving ship.
These are some of the oldest trees in the world.

meanings.def: former; belonging to past times or a past time in your life
examples: Things were different in the old days.
I went back to visit my old school.
Old and Middle English
People are still clinging to the old ways of thinking.

meanings.def: used to refer to something that has been replaced by something else
examples: We had more room in our old house.
Mum and Dad bought us a fridge and gave us their old telly.

meanings.def: known for a long time
examples: She's an old friend of mine (= I have known her for a long time).
We're old rivals.
It's always the same old faces.
The album includes both new titles and old favourites.

meanings.def: used to show kind feelings or a lack of respect
examples: Good old Dad!
You poor old thing!
I hate her, the silly old cow!
It's a funny old world.
Why drink plain old water when you can have something better?
They were having the same boring old conversation about school.
As my dear old Grandma used to say…

meanings.def: any item of the type mentioned (used when it is not important which particular item is chosen)
examples: Any old room would have done.

meanings.def: in a careless or untidy way
examples: The books were piled up all over the floor any old how.

meanings.def: very old; ancient
to be behaving in the same bad way as before
examples: He had soon spent all the money and was up to his old tricks.

meanings.def: a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave
if you do something for old times’ sake, you do it because it is connected with something good that happened to you in the past
to dismiss somebody from their job; to end a relationship with somebody
an earlier period of time in your life or in history that is seen as better/worse than the present
examples: That was in the bad old days of rampant inflation.

meanings.def: a great age
examples: She finally learned to drive at the grand old age of 70.

meanings.def: a man who is respected in a particular profession that he has been involved in for a long time
examples: James Lovelock, the grand old man of environmental science

meanings.def: to enjoy yourself very much
used to give an amount, a measurement, etc. using older or more traditional units that may be more familiar to some people
examples: The fish measured 29 centimetres (that's a foot in old money).

meanings.def: money that is earned very easily, for something that needs little effort
examples: The job only took about an hour—it was money for old rope.

meanings.def: an older person who behaves in a stupid way is worse than a younger person who does the same thing, because experience should have taught him or her not to do it
in or since past times
examples: in days of old
We know him of old (= we have known him for a long time).

meanings.def: used by older men of the middle and upper classes as a friendly way of addressing another man
very much older than somebody (especially used to suggest that a romantic or sexual relationship between the two people is not appropriate)
old enough to behave in a more sensible way than you actually did
used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
what usually happens
examples: It's the same old story of a badly managed project with inadequate funding.

meanings.def: an old idea or belief that people now know is not correct
an old-fashioned person who likes to do things as they were done in the past
an age that is considered to be very old
examples: He lived to the ripe old age of 91.

meanings.def: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past
examples: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.

meanings.def: (you cannot) successfully make people change their ideas, methods of work, etc., when they have had them for a long time
very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
examples: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.

idioms.def: any item of the type mentioned (used when it is not important which particular item is chosen)
examples: Any old room would have done.

idioms.def: in a careless or untidy way
examples: The books were piled up all over the floor any old how.

idioms.def: very old; ancient
to be behaving in the same bad way as before
examples: He had soon spent all the money and was up to his old tricks.

idioms.idiom: a chip off the old block
idioms.def: a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave
if you do something for old times’ sake, you do it because it is connected with something good that happened to you in the past
to dismiss somebody from their job; to end a relationship with somebody
an earlier period of time in your life or in history that is seen as better/worse than the present
examples: That was in the bad old days of rampant inflation.

idioms.def: a great age
examples: She finally learned to drive at the grand old age of 70.

idioms.def: a man who is respected in a particular profession that he has been involved in for a long time
examples: James Lovelock, the grand old man of environmental science

idioms.def: to enjoy yourself very much
used to give an amount, a measurement, etc. using older or more traditional units that may be more familiar to some people
examples: The fish measured 29 centimetres (that's a foot in old money).

idioms.def: money that is earned very easily, for something that needs little effort
examples: The job only took about an hour—it was money for old rope.

idioms.idiom: (there’s) no fool like an old fool
idioms.def: an older person who behaves in a stupid way is worse than a younger person who does the same thing, because experience should have taught him or her not to do it
in or since past times
examples: in days of old
We know him of old (= we have known him for a long time).

idioms.def: used by older men of the middle and upper classes as a friendly way of addressing another man

idioms.idiom: old enough to be somebody’s father/mother
idioms.def: very much older than somebody (especially used to suggest that a romantic or sexual relationship between the two people is not appropriate)
old enough to behave in a more sensible way than you actually did

idioms.idiom: (have) an old head on young shoulders
idioms.def: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
what usually happens
examples: It's the same old story of a badly managed project with inadequate funding.

idioms.def: an old idea or belief that people now know is not correct
an old-fashioned person who likes to do things as they were done in the past
an age that is considered to be very old
examples: He lived to the ripe old age of 91.

idioms.idiom: settle a score/accounts (with somebody) | settle an old score
idioms.def: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past
examples: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.

idioms.idiom: (you can’t) teach an old dog new tricks
idioms.def: (you cannot) successfully make people change their ideas, methods of work, etc., when they have had them for a long time

idioms.idiom: (as) tough as old boots | (as) tough as nails
idioms.def: very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
examples: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.
